newsitem.title: USA: Circus Circus unveils plan for new resort.
newsitem.headline: Circus Circus unveils plan for new resort.

text.p: Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. unveiled plans Tuesday to build a 4,000-room resort casino modelled on a South Sea island in Las Vegas, starting with the planned destruction of the Hacienda Hotel on New Year's Eve.

The Hacienda, which is to be blown up on national television, sits on the site along Vegas' famed "Strip" where the resort for upscale tourists and high-rolling gamblers that is code-named Project Paradise will be built.
The resort will attempt to recreate a South Seas island and will include jungle foliage, waterfalls and terraced gardens, the Las Vegas-based company said in a statement.
At its centre will be a wave-washed beach, reef and tropical fish among which visitors can snorkle. Next to that will be a shark-filled tank they can swim by.
Construction is slated to start in February and end in fall of 1998, said Circus Circus, a major U.S. gambling company.
Circus Circus declined to give a cost estimate for the project, saying a final budget will be announced in the next few months.
Financial analysts and published reports have put the cost anywhere between $700 million and $1 billion. Company executives were not immediately available to comment.
The project will be financed through cash flow and bank lines of credit, the company said in a statement.
The company owns and operates 10 properties in Nevada, including the themed Circus Circus, Excalibur and Luxor hotels and casinos in Las Vegas.
Circus Circus stock dropped 37.5 cents to $34.375 in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
